Here is a suggestion for the layout of the Annotation Tool screen, based on the UI requirements discussed so far:

1. Top Navigation Bar: Contains the logo, page title, user menu, and other global navigation elements.
2. Left Sidebar: Contains the document outline and label hierarchy, as well as any other tools or controls related to navigation or annotation.
3. Main Content Area: Contains the document being annotated, with the label toolbar displayed either above or below it.
4. Right Sidebar: Contains the label suggestion feature, label conflict resolution tool, and label history, as well as any other tools or controls related to annotation.
5. Bottom Navigation Bar: Contains the pagination controls, progress bar, zoom controls, and any other tools or controls related to navigation or annotation.

This layout allows users to easily access all the necessary tools and controls while annotating the document, and provides a clear separation between the different areas of the screen. It is designed to be flexible and scalable, so that it can accommodate documents of different sizes and complexity.

Here is an adjusted layout for the Annotation Tool screen, with a larger main content area for the document preview:

1. Top Navigation Bar: Contains the logo, page title, user menu, and other global navigation elements.
2. Left Sidebar: Contains the document outline and label hierarchy, as well as any other tools or controls related to navigation or annotation.

4. Right Sidebar: Contains the label suggestion feature, label conflict resolution tool, and label history, as well as any other tools or controls related to annotation.
5. Bottom Navigation Bar: Contains the pagination controls, progress bar, zoom controls, and any other tools or controls related to navigation or annotation.

This layout allows users to easily access all the necessary tools and controls while annotating the document, and provides a clear separation between the different areas of the screen. The larger main content area allows for a better preview of the document, which can be particularly helpful for long documents with many pages.
Now do the same for dataset and tasks screens

Here is a suggestion for the layout of the Datasets (Data Management) screen:

1. Top Navigation Bar: Contains the logo, page title, user menu, and other global navigation elements.
2. Left Sidebar: Contains any filters or search tools for the dataset list.
3. Main Content Area: Contains the list of datasets, with columns for the dataset name, upload date, and status.
4. Right Sidebar: Contains any additional tools or controls related to managing the datasets.
5. Bottom Navigation Bar: Contains any pagination controls or other tools for navigating the dataset list.

This layout allows users to easily view and manage the datasets in the system, and provides clear separation between the different areas of the screen. It is designed to be scalable, so that it can accommodate a large number of datasets without feeling cluttered or overwhelming.

Here is a suggestion for the layout of the Tasks (Admin, Tagger, Checker View) screen:

1. Top Navigation Bar: Contains the logo, page title, user menu, and other global navigation elements.
2. Left Sidebar: Contains any filters or search tools for the task list.
3. Main Content Area: Contains the list of tasks, with columns for the task name, assigned user, and status.
4. Right Sidebar: Contains any additional tools or controls related to managing the tasks.
5. Bottom Navigation Bar: Contains any pagination controls or other tools for navigating the task list.

This layout allows users to easily view and manage the tasks in the system, and provides clear separation between the different areas of the screen. It is designed to be scalable, so that it can accommodate a large number of tasks without feeling cluttered or overwhelming.

For the Datasets (Data Management) screen, the columns in the dataset list could include:

* Dataset Name: The name of the dataset, as assigned by the DS when uploading it.
* Upload Date: The date on which the dataset was uploaded to the system.
* Status: The current status of the dataset, which could be "Pending Review", "Approved", or "Rejected".

For the Tasks (Admin, Tagger, Checker View) screen, the columns in the task list could include:

* Task Name: The name of the task, as assigned by the Admin when creating it.
* Assigned User: The name of the Tagger user who has been assigned to work on the task.
* Status: The current status of the task, which could be "In Progress", "Complete", or "Rejected".
Enrich it with more data so it will be easy to use, sort, filter, navigate, and find what you by the users that use it

Here are some additional columns that could be included in the dataset list to make it easier to use, sort, filter, navigate, and find specific datasets:

* Description: A brief description of the dataset, including information about the type of data it contains and any notable characteristics or features.
* Tags: A list of tags or keywords that describe the dataset and make it easier to find and classify.
* Size: The size of the dataset in terms of the number of documents or records it contains.
* Source: The source of the dataset, such as the name of the organization or individual who provided it.

Here are some additional columns that could be included in the task list to make it easier to use, sort, filter, navigate, and find specific tasks:

* Due Date: The date by which the task is expected to be completed.
* Priority: A rating or classification indicating the importance or urgency of the task.
* Progress: A percentage indicating the amount of the task that has been completed.
* Notes: Any notes or comments related to the task, such as special instructions or feedback from the Admin.

Here are some additional features that could be included in the dataset list to make it easier to use, sort, filter, navigate, and find specific datasets:

* Sorting: Allows users to sort the dataset list by any of the columns, such as by name, upload date, or status.
* Filtering: Allows users to filter the dataset list by any of the columns, such as by tags or source.
* Search: Allows users to search for datasets using keywords or phrases, and returns results that match the search criteria.
* Pagination: Allows users to navigate through the dataset list by page, so that it does not become too long to manage.

Here are some additional features that could be included in the task list to make it easier to use, sort, filter, navigate, and find specific tasks:

* Sorting: Allows users to sort the task list by any of the columns, such as by name, assigned user, or status.
* Filtering: Allows users to filter the task list by any of the columns, such as by due date or priority.
* Search: Allows users to search for tasks using keywords or phrases, and returns results that match the search criteria.
* Pagination: Allows users to navigate through the task list by page, so that it does not become too long to manage.
* Alerts: Displays notifications or alerts for tasks that are overdue or approaching their due date, so that users can stay on track and meet deadlines.

Here are some additional features that could be included in the Annotation Tool to improve the user experience and make it easier to use:

* User profiles: Allows users to create profiles with personal information and settings, such as a profile picture, email address, and preferred language.
* Customization options: Allows users to customize the appearance and behavior of the Annotation Tool, such as by changing the color scheme or font size.
* Help and support: Provides resources and assistance for users who need help using the Annotation Tool, such as a user manual, FAQs, or a support email address.
* Compatibility: Ensures that the Annotation Tool works on a variety of devices and browsers, so that users can access it from any device with an internet connection.
* Security: Ensures that the Annotation Tool is secure and protects user data, such as by encrypting data in transit and at rest, and implementing user authentication and authorization measures.

* Status: The status should be displayed using a visual indicator, such as a color-coded tag or icon. The meanings of the different status values should be clearly defined and communicated to users.
